node.title: Covid-19 wrap: MIQ changes and traffic light legislation
node.description: There were 215 new Covid-19 cases announced today, the country's most restrictive border controls will be eased early next year, and MPs pass traffic light legislation.

node.title: Samsung to build a new semiconductor facility in Texas
node.description: The $17 billion chip factory is largest U.S. investment ever by the South Korean electronics giant, it said.

node.title: It’s Beginning to Look a Lot Like Holiday Social Anxiety
node.description: Even in the best of times, social gatherings can be overwhelming. If you’re feeling less-than-festive, here’s how to ease into the season.

node.title: Art Basel Miami Beach Returns, Smaller but Ready to Party
node.description: What you’ll find at this year’s tropical circus: hundreds of galleries, institutions proudly exhibiting homegrown work and an array of NFT-themed gatherings.

node.title: The head of Instagram agrees to testify as Congress probes the app’s effects on young people.
node.description: This will be the first time Adam Mosseri, a trusted lieutenant to Mark Zuckerberg, will testify to lawmakers under oath.

node.title: British Lawmaker Is Reprimanded for Bringing Her Baby to a Debate
node.description: Stella Creasy received a letter of complaint for attending a debate with her infant son in tow. After an outcry, the speaker of the House of Commons said that a committee would review the rules.

node.title: NASA Curiosity Rover Captures Spectacular Images of Mars Landscape
node.description: Curiosity has been exploring the red planet and gathering scientific data for almost a decade, having touched down on the surface on August 5, 2012.

node.title: Hubble Spots Superhot Shockwave Coming From Running Man Nebula
node.description: The blast from deep space, known as a Herbig-Haro object, is thought to have come from a newborn star.

node.title: Why tapping oil reserves may not do much to curb gas prices
node.description: White House plan aims to offer relief to millions of motorists. But the gains are likely to be modest, according to experts.

node.title: ‘Resident Evil: Welcome to Raccoon City’ Review: They Go Way Back
node.description: Set in 1998, this franchise origin story embraces nostalgia.

node.title: A Fix-It Job for Government Tech
node.description: To build trust in the government, it would help if the website worked.

node.title: Space Pagans and Smartphone Witches: Where Tech Meets Mysticism
node.description: The internet allows us to discover, select and combine the spiritual traditions that suit us best. In a new exhibition, artists are exploring the connections between ancient beliefs and futuristic systems.

node.title: Migrants Feared Dead After Boat Capsizes in English Channel
node.description: The boat, which was carrying the migrants to Britain, capsized near Calais. The French authorities said “many” people had died in the accident.

node.title: When Is Cyber Monday? 2021 Date, Early Deals and History
node.description: Cyber Monday is on the horizon and will follow up Black Friday with bargains galore! Here is all you need to know about the event, including when it starts.

node.title: Emaciated Humpback Whale That Died Entangled in Fishing Gear Found in Massachusetts
node.description: A necropsy revealed that the whale had an empty stomach, a sign of "chronic entanglement."

node.title: Do We Get Paid Early for Thanksgiving? How the Federal Holiday Affects Your Paycheck
node.description: Many banks, including the Federal Reserve, are closed on federal holidays. Does this mean workers get paid early for Thanksgiving?

node.title: 20 Italian Towns Put Into Lockdown as Effort to Control COVID Spread
node.description: Bars and restaurants in the towns must close after 6 p.m. and residents must comply with a nighttime curfew between 8 p.m. and 5 a.m.

node.title: EU Eyes Sanctions for Airlines, Tourism Companies Aiding Migrants Entrance to Belarus
node.description: The sanctions are expected to be approved by EU leaders in the coming days.

node.title: Russia Wants to Broker an Iran-Saudi Deal and Biden Doesn't Seem to Mind
node.description: "Neither the United States nor Russia is interested in having this war," Vitaly Naumkin, co-author of Moscow's Persian Gulf security plan, told Newsweek.

node.title: Large Ice Cream Manufacturer Faces Boycotts for Raising Wage of Vaccinated Workers
node.description: Chapman's Ice Cream Company is offering a $1-per-hour raise for employees that get vaccinated by the end of the month.

node.title: Winter COVID Surge Starts Hitting States With High Vaccination Rates
node.description: Of the states seeing the largest uptick in COVID-19 cases, only two have vaccinated fewer than 70 percent of its adult population.

node.title: IRS Reports 25 Percent of Workforce Got COVID Vaccine After Biden Mandate Issued
node.description: Monday was the deadline for 3.5 million federal workers to get their first COVID-19 shot, and 92 percent reported that they were at least partially vaccinated.

node.title: Lake Waikaremoana off limits as Tūhoe tries to raise vaccination rates
node.description: One of the country's Great Walks is off limits while the iwi that has responsibility over the area tries to get vaccination rates up. Audio

node.title: Couple new to U.S. gets hundreds of invites to Thanksgiving
node.description: "People are kindness, people are love," said Susana Orrego, a student at Harvard Medical School.

node.title: Yotam Ottolenghi’s Rules for Brunch
node.description: When it comes to planning a festive meal, the chef has certain specifications. This custardy butternut squash meets them all.

node.title: A Pioneering British Artist’s Painting of a Negotiation
node.description: Ahead of her solo exhibition at the Tate Modern in London, Lubaina Himid shares a new, exclusive work.

node.title: The Fed’s preferred measure of inflation surged again in October amid rising food and energy prices.
node.description: Prices climbed by 5 percent in the 12 months through October, according to Personal Consumption Expenditures price index data released Wednesday.

node.title: For Afghan Refugees, a Choice Between Community and Opportunity
node.description: In resettling thousands of displaced Afghans, the Biden administration must weigh their need for support against the needs of the U.S. labor market.

node.title: Meet Genesis, a High School Senior in N.Y.C.
node.description: She’s spent the pandemic helping her younger sister get through kindergarten, while keeping an eye trained on college.

node.title: Teen Girl Finds Bronze Age Axe on Third Day Metal Detecting
node.description: The 13-year-old girl in Hertfordshire in the U.K. turned up a further 64 artifacts dating back to 1300 BC.

node.title: South Korea Sets Record for New COVID Cases, Largely Concentrated in Seoul
node.description: The Korea Disease Control and Prevention Agency recorded 4,116 new COVID-19 infections on Wednesday.

node.title: 2 Chinese Activists Who Supported #MeToo Movement, Also Disappeared Like Peng Shuai
node.description: Activists Huang Xueqin and Wang Jianbing, who helped women come forward on sexual assault, haven't been heard from since their arrests in September.

node.title: Wild Buck Trapped in Classroom After Breaking Into Elementary School
node.description: The deer knocked over tables and chairs in the classroom as it looked for a way to get out of the school.

node.title: Thanksgiving Eve
node.description: Chop some vegetables, defrost the pie crusts, set the table, but most importantly, relax.

node.title: ‘Drive My Car’ Review: A Director Takes Your Heart for a Spin
node.description: In this quiet masterpiece, Ryusuke Hamaguchi considers grief, love, work and the soul-sustaining, life-shaping power of art.

node.title: Mickey Guyton on Her Grammy Nominations: ‘I Was Right’
node.description: Last Grammys, the singer became the first Black woman to be nominated for a solo country performance award. This time, she’s back with three more chances to win.

node.title: Cultivating Art, Not Argument, at a Los Angeles Law Office
node.description: Their office-tower studios could not be less bohemian, but the artists in residence at a law firm’s offices in California say the spaces spur creativity nonetheless.

node.title: Strained Massachusetts hospitals will cut back on elective procedures starting Monday.
node.description: Health officials cited pandemic staffing shortages and longer hospital stays for those who earlier delayed treatment; Covid cases are far from the state’s peak.

node.title: Europe reckons with calls for Covid restrictions to avoid a bleak winter.
node.description: The European Center for Disease Prevention and Control called for  “urgently” tightening restrictions and closing vaccination gaps, and recommended booster shots for all adults.

node.title: Multiverse Theory Explained Ahead of 'Spider-Man: No Way Home' Release
node.description: The concept of multiple universes coexisting is a popular one in science fiction like the forthcoming Marvel movie but it is founded in science theory.

node.title: Putin Confirms He's Taken COVID Booster Shot, Followed by Experimental Nasal Vaccine
node.description: "Today, after these two procedures, I already did some sport in the morning," Putin said during a cabinet meeting.

node.title: China Says U.S. Will Embarrass Itself by Platforming Taiwan at Joe Biden's Summit
node.description: China voiced firm opposition to Taiwan's participation at the upcoming "Summit for Democracy"—an event that was one of Joe Biden's campaign pledges in July 2019.

node.title: Ethiopia's Prime Minister Goes to Battlefield, Igniting Fears of Plans to Be War Martyr
node.description: "If (Abiy) gets hurt or killed, it's not just the federal government that will collapse, the army will as well," said an International IDEA researcher.

node.title: Netherlands 10 Days Away From Health Care Rationing, Doctor Warns in Lockdown Appeal
node.description: The Netherlands saw an overall 39 percent spike in infections in the past week. Children ages 5 to 11 had the highest rate of COVID-19 infections.

node.title: Marjorie Taylor Greene Sponsors Bill to Award Kyle Rittenhouse a Congressional Gold Medal
node.description: The proposed recognition cites Rittenhouse "protect(ing) the community of Kenosha, Wisconsin, during a Black Lives Matter (BLM) riot on August 25, 2020."

node.title: Gabby Petito Lawyer Says 'Additional Individuals' May Face Charges in Her Murder
node.description: Richard Stafford's comments came just days after authorities confirmed Brian Laundrie had died via a self-inflected gunshot.

node.title: Fauci Accuses Tucker Carlson of Killing People by 'Weaponizing Lies'
node.description: The president's chief medical adviser said he considered criticism from certain people to be "a badge of honor."

node.title: Old Spice, Secret Deodorant Sprays Recalled Over Possible Cancer Concerns
node.description: The recall notice said that the level of benzene found in the specific products "would not be expected to cause adverse health consequences."

node.title: New U.S. Unemployment Claims at Lowest Number Since 1969, Now Less Than 200K
node.description: The shift could signal that the U.S. job market is bouncing back from when the COVID-19 pandemic slammed the economy last year and many people lost work.

node.title: Sweden's Parliament approves first female Prime Minister
node.description: Social Democrat leader Magdalena Andersson's approval is a milestone for Sweden, and means three out of five Nordic countries have female leaders.

node.title: German coalition parties sign agreement deal to end Angela Merkel's 16-year grip on power
node.description: The three-party coalition agreement is a departure from Ms Merkel's conservative-led government's agenda, with a push towards renewable energy and a plan to phase out coal by 2030.

node.title: Jamie Dimon walks back his quip about China’s Communist Party.
node.description: “I regret and should not have made that comment,” the chief executive of JPMorgan Chase said Wednesday.

node.title: Dog Recovering After Horrendous Beating That Saw Two Others Killed
node.description: "It took somebody really mad to do what they did to those dogs," said Texas animal rescuer Brat Hilton.

node.title: "Sunday Morning" primetime special: "Forever Young: Searching for the Fountain of Youth" (November 28)
node.description: Jane Pauley hosts a one-hour primetime special exploring the wonders, rewards, and challenges of growing older, featuring interviews with Candice Bergen and Billy Crystal, and recent developments in the study of extending human life.

node.title: Scammers taking advantage of supply chain issues with fake websites
node.description: LexisNexis Risk Solutions has seen a 2,000% increase in consumers who say they've lost money to scammers posing as legitimate online retailers, company CEO Haywood Talcove said.

node.title: Not Your Traditional Hanukkah/Christmas Picture Book
node.description: When a stone thrower extinguishes a menorah’s lights in Lee Wind’s “Red and Green and Blue and White,” a community bands together.

node.title: Jewish Pride, and Prejudice, in Veera Hiranandani’s New Middle Grade Novel
node.description: “How to Find What You’re Not Looking For” views the elopement of a Jewish girl with a Hindu boy through the lens of Loving v. Virginia.

node.title: Republicans Blame Biden for Pandemic’s Persistence
node.description: Republicans have fought mask requirements and vaccine mandates for months, but as coronavirus infections again rise, they are blaming the president for failing to end the health crisis.

node.title: The coalition agreement goes into detail. It’s a German tradition.
node.description: Sometimes long, sometimes laborious, coalition agreements have helped ensure the durability of German governments — mostly.

node.title: Iran Rebuffs U.N. Watchdog on Resuming Nuclear Inspections
node.description: The head of the U.N. nuclear agency said Tehran continues to refuse to let it replace key monitoring equipment that tracks the country’s nuclear program.

node.title: He Convinced Voters He Would Be Like Merkel. But Who Is Olaf Scholz?
node.description: Germany’s next chancellor is something of an enigma. He comes to power with a dizzying array of challenges, raising questions about whether he can fill the very big shoes of his predecessor.

node.title: Almost half of humanity is eating too much or too little, report says
node.description: The Global Nutrition Report and other recent research shows a major gulf in diets around the world, with a big impact not only on our health, but the health of our planet.

node.title: Waukesha parade crash victim remembered as "a beautiful person"
node.description: John Kulich said his last day with his wife began at church listening to a sermon about great couples.

node.title: ‘8-Bit Christmas’ Review: Now You’re Playing With Power
node.description: Nintendo looms large in this sentimental, 1980s-set holiday comedy.

node.title: ‘A Boy Called Christmas’ Review: Kindling the Holiday Spirit
node.description: Enchanting imagery elevates this Netflix holiday adventure about a boy who journeys to a magic elfin city.

node.title: Maya Lin’s Dismantled ‘Ghost Forest’ to Be Reborn as Boats
node.description: Teenagers are making boats using the wood from her grove installation at Madison Square Park, and the artist is happy that the work is seeing a new life.

node.title: He’s the Brusque Mr. Fix-It for Mexico City’s Accordions
node.description: For 50 years, Francisco Luis Ramírez has been the go-to guy for instrument repairs in a nation that reveres the accordion. Now it’s a family business.

node.title: China Accused of 'Harassment' in South China Sea After Vowing to Back Down
node.description: Chinese government vessels continued to follow and photograph Philippine boats resupplying troops on a disputed South China Sea atoll on Tuesday, Manila said.

node.title: Ben Crump Says Defense Attorney Suggested Arbery Was A 'Runaway Slave' in Toenail Comment
node.description: "It's Trayvon Martin 2.0," Crump said, describing the defense's efforts to characterize Arbery as a "scary, Black man" in their closing arguments.

node.title: Online Tool Calculates Risk of COVID Exposure at Thanksgiving Gatherings
node.description: The tool comes as vaccinated Americans have been given the OK by health experts to gather for the holiday season.

node.title: Her Art Reads the Land in Deep Time
node.description: Athena LaTocha has embraced geological materials from mesas, wetlands and bluffs in her large-scale works. Now, she’s exploring what’s underfoot in New York City.

node.title: Why Some Dads Don’t Take Leave: They Think They’ll Be Punished
node.description: Until everyone has it, paid parental leave will be seen as nonessential.

node.title: Scientists Peer Hundreds of Feet Beneath the Surface of Mars, Find Ancient Lava
node.description: Using incredibly sensitive instruments, the researchers were able to map more than 600 feet beneath the surface of the Red Planet, finding dried lava.

node.title: Woman welcomes first baby at 50
node.description: "As I was starting the c-section, Susie was humming a gospel song that I am very familiar with. I knew we were both in good hands," her doctor sad.

node.title: Russian docking module launched to space station
node.description: The module will use a Russian "space tug" to rendezvous with the space station Friday.

node.title: House Hunting in Brazil: A 19th-Century House on the Coast
node.description: Following a severe recession in 2015 and 2016, Brazil’s housing market began a period of slow recovery, which accelerated during the pandemic.

node.title: It's Been 5 Months Since Kamala Harris Visited the Border—What Has She Said Since?
node.description: The vice president has faced criticism for her role in responding to the border crisis. But with the number of migrant crossings on the decline, her mission to address root causes could finally be paying off.

node.title: Some GOP states carve out "natural immunity" COVID vaccine exceptions
node.description: But currently authorized tests cannot measure how much protection you actually have from a prior infection.

node.title: A slate of foreign policy crises awaits the new chancellor.
node.description: Olaf Scholz will be confronted with an extraordinary array of troubles on the international stage that will test his mettle quickly.

node.title: COVID leaves Cyprus stockpiling millions of kilograms of halloumi
node.description: For many it's a staple of a BBQ but in Cyprus right now they have halloumi stockpiled in the millions of kilograms as the pandemic impacts exports badly.

node.title: Ethiopia's PM heads to front lines to personally direct fight against Tigray forces
node.description: The government says Abiy Ahmed has gone to take charge in a yearlong war,  leaving daily work of running the country to his deputy, as rival fighters approach the capital Addis Ababa.

node.title: Biden selects two women to lead Office of Management and Budget
node.description: The president will nominate Shalanda Young as the agency's chief. She'd be first Black woman in the post. And he'll name Nani Coloretti, who is Asian American, as deputy.

node.title: Scientists work to decode Moderna's COVID vaccine to help Africa
node.description: Only 5% of Africans are fully vaccinated against the coronavirus, thanks largely to big pharmaceutical companies supplying wealthy nations first. Rebels in lab coats are trying to redress the imbalance.

node.title: What should U.S. immigration policy be?
node.description: A CBS News poll takes a closer look at what's behind immigration views.

node.title: Jobless claims plunge to their lowest level in 52 years
node.description: Fewer than 200,000 Americans filed for unemployment benefits last week, the lowest figure since the pandemic struck.

node.title: "General Hospital" actor Steve Burton fired for refusing vaccine
node.description: Steve Burton has intermittently starred on the soap opera since 1992, portraying the character of Jason Morgan.

node.title: $900,000 Homes in Illinois, Pennsylvania and Colorado
node.description: A modern retreat in DeKalb, a circa-1800 home in New Hope and a 1906 Edwardian house in Denver.

node.title: What to Read: Four Children’s Books
node.description: A selection of books published this week.

node.title: Once a Warrior, Then a Nonprofit Leader, Now an Entrepreneur
node.description: Jake Wood was a Marine sniper in Iraq and Afghanistan. Now he works in the philanthropic sector and is “leading with love.”

node.title: The Best Tech Gifts That Aren’t Gadgets
node.description: Supply-chain disruptions may make it tough to buy devices, but the most thoughtful presents were never tangible to begin with.

node.title: Waukesha Suspect Darrell Brooks Should Not Have Been Released On Bail—Wisconsin Lawmaker
node.description: Darrell Brooks, 39, was released on $1,000 bail days before he allegedly plowed through a Christmas parade in Wisconsin.

node.title: Great White Sharks Gather Off the Coasts of Virginia and North Carolina
node.description: Ocean trackers have shown at least seven of the enormous predators off the coasts of the two states in recent weeks.

node.title: The U.S. has a new UFO task force
node.description: A June report showed that of 144 reports of unidentified flying objects government officials investigated, only one was able to be definitively explained.

node.title: Heady Jewels to Keep the Holiday Season Bright
node.description: Whether pear-shaped or pavé, set in platinum or gold, diamonds bring radiance to even the darkest winters.

node.title: Lisa, star of the K-pop group Blackpink, tests positive for Covid.
node.description: The group’s three other members are awaiting test results.

node.title: San Diego’s Oldest Women’s Basketball Players on Why They Play
node.description: A senior league offers community and competition for women as old as 95.

node.title: What’s next for Angela Merkel?
node.description: After 16 years as chancellor, there is no shortage of speculation about what her second act will be.

node.title: National energy market report reveals expected price drops for power bills across country
node.description: Household power bills are predicted to continue falling across Australia in the coming years, a new report says, despite the closure of major sites such as the Liddell power station in NSW.

node.title: Black Friday starts early, but expect fewer holiday deals
node.description: Poll shows Americans plan to spend an average of $886 on gifts this season, up slightly from last year.

node.title: ‘Keep Sweet’ Review: A Legacy of Polygamy in a Religious Sect
node.description: This documentary by Don Argott looks to the past and future of a community in the American West that made its own rules and lived by them.
